title: Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) for Pediatric Withdrawal
description: Validated assessment tool for evaluating opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal severity in pediatric patients. The WAT-1 systematically assesses 12 clinical parameters across multiple domains including neurologic irritability, motor symptoms, respiratory distress, and gastrointestinal symptoms to guide withdrawal management in children.

parameters.name: post_menstrual_age_weeks
parameters.description: Post-menstrual age in weeks (gestational age + chronological age)

parameters.name: state_sleep_wake_cycle
parameters.description: State/sleep-wake cycle disturbance (0=normal sleep, 1=mild restlessness, 2=moderate agitation, 3=severe sleep disturbance)

parameters.name: tremor
parameters.description: Tremor severity (0=none, 1=mild when stimulated, 2=moderate when awake, 3=severe continuous)

parameters.name: increased_muscle_tone
parameters.description: Increased muscle tone/hypertonia (0=normal, 1=mild increase, 2=moderate increase, 3=severe rigidity)

parameters.name: excoriation
parameters.description: Excoriation marks from scratching (0=none, 1=red marks, 2=scratches without bleeding, 3=bleeding scratches)

parameters.name: myoclonus_seizures
parameters.description: Myoclonus/seizure activity (0=none, 1=occasional jerks, 2=frequent jerks, 3=continuous or seizures)

parameters.name: tachypnea
parameters.description: Tachypnea/respiratory distress (0=normal rate, 1=mildly elevated, 2=moderately elevated, 3=severely elevated or distressed)

parameters.name: poor_feeding_vomiting
parameters.description: Poor feeding/vomiting (0=normal feeding, 1=poor feeding, 2=refusal to feed, 3=vomiting)

result.name: wat_1_score
result.description: WAT-1 total score for pediatric withdrawal severity

ranges.description: No withdrawal or mild withdrawal symptoms
ranges.interpretation: WAT-1 score indicates no significant withdrawal or very mild withdrawal symptoms. Continue current management and monitor for symptom progression. Consider comfort measures and supportive care as needed.

WAT-1 score suggests mild to moderate withdrawal symptoms requiring intervention. Consider pharmacological management with appropriate medications. Increase monitoring frequency and provide comfort measures.

WAT-1 score indicates moderate to severe withdrawal requiring immediate pharmacological intervention. Consider methadone, morphine, or clonidine as appropriate. Provide intensive monitoring and supportive care.

references: Franck LS, Harris SK, Soetenga DJ, et al. The Withdrawal Assessment Tool-1 (WAT-1): an assessment instrument for monitoring opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms in pediatric patients. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2008;9(6):573-580. doi: 10.1097/PCC.0b013e31818c8328
Anand KJ, Willson DF, Berger J, et al. Tolerance and withdrawal from prolonged opioid use in critically ill children. Pediatrics. 2010;125(5):e1208-e1225. doi: 10.1542/peds.2009-0489

Ista E, van Dijk M, Gamel C, et al. Withdrawal symptoms in children after long-term administration of sedatives and/or analgesics: a literature review. Assessment remains troublesome. Intensive Care Med. 2007;33(8):1396-1406. doi: 10.1007/s00134-007-0696-x

Best KM, Asaro LA, Franck LS. Patterns of sedation weaning in critically ill children recovering from acute respiratory failure. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2015;16(3):e43-e49. doi: 10.1097/PCC.0000000000000324
formula: Sum of scores for 12 withdrawal assessment parameters (0-3 points each): state/sleep-wake cycle + tremor + increased muscle tone + excoriation + myoclonus/seizures + tachypnea + sweating + fever + frequent yawning/sneezing + nasal stuffiness + poor feeding/vomiting. Post-menstrual age affects interpretation thresholds.
notes: Validated for pediatric patients (term infants to 18 years)
Assesses withdrawal from opioids and benzodiazepines
Should be assessed every 4-12 hours during withdrawal period
Post-menstrual age affects expected baseline behaviors
Younger patients may have different manifestations
Tool helps standardize withdrawal assessment across providers
Useful for guiding weaning protocols and medication decisions
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Not validated for alcohol or other substance withdrawal
Environmental modifications may help reduce scores
Family presence and comfort measures are important adjuncts
Consider pain vs withdrawal as differential diagnosis
Age-appropriate comfort measures should be implemented
